How many a scene in life demands our tears!</br>Thick on the heart what sad reflections press!</br>At ev'ry turn some sight of woe appears,</br>At ev'ry step some object of distress.
Of those who once in fortune's splendour shone,</br>By crouds attended, by the world carest,</br>How many a sigh, neglected and unknown,</br>Or known but as insulted and opprest!
This shapeless mass, which mud and filth disgrace,</br>The helpless victim of the pelting storm,</br>Whose faded beauties Taste no more can trace,</br>Or ev'n Conjecture analyse its form;
Was once a Wig — How alter'd now its state!</br>Where are its beauties now?  its glories where?</br>Distinguish'd by the notice of the great,</br>Grac'd by the admiration of the fair?
Gone — gone! — O Wig! — Yet, while thou bidst adieu</br>To all the glories of each once gay scene,</br>Fain would the muse ('tis all she can) renew</br>The mem'ry of what thou, alas!  hast been:
For tho' cast off, neglected and forgot,</br>'Twas once thy fate in other scenes to shine;</br>Thine was in happier times a splendid lot;</br>Beauty and worth and dignity were thine.
Some Judge sagacious, learned in the law,</br>Us'd thee, perhaps, his solemn frown t' improve;</br>While culprits, juries, courts, with rev'rend awe,</br>Shook like Olympus at the nod of Jove.
Some grave professor's head has been thy place;</br>Haply 'twas thine his office to bespeak,</br>While, clinging closely round his classic face,</br>Each learned curl seem'd buckled stiff with Greek.
Some bard, perhaps, in meditation deep,</br>Some student hard of Demosthenian stamp,</br>Giving to study the soft hours of sleep,</br>Has sing'd thy tresses at the midnight lamp.
Or it has been thy niggard lot to bind</br>Some miser's wrinkled brow, (while o'er his chest</br>He hung, with base idolatry inclin'd,)</br>Whose "auri sacra fames" broke his rest.

Thou mayst have grac'd some Doctor's sapient phiz,</br>Like owl in snow-clad bush with solemn pride,</br>Whose patients seem'd to hear the harmless whiz</br>Of Death's weak shafts, turn'd by his art aside.
Or, sentenc'd to a more ignoble fate,</br>Thou may'st have hung upon an empty scull;</br>For Wisdom's ensigns oft give Folly state,</br>And many a rev'rend wig adorns a fool.
Fain would the muse proceed — but what avails</br>That once thou hast sustain'd a splendid part?—</br>Sad Truth condemns such visionary tales,</br>And turns her steady eye to what thou art.
Like Woolsey, thou hast bid a long farewell</br>To all thy greatness; all thy pomp is o'er;</br>No more dost thou the pride of grandeur swell;</br>Plebeians tremble at thy nod no more.
What art thou now?  disgrac'd, soil'd, mangled, torn,</br>Neglected, save that the mischievous dog</br>Shakes thee in sportive rage, or, more forlorn,</br>Thou form'st a pillow for the wallowing hog.
Thus, buried far amid the sandy waste,</br>Palmyra's broken columns meet the eye;</br>Thus Nimrod's lofty walls no more are trac'd;</br>Thus Israel's sacred domes in ruins lie.
"The cloud-capt towers, the gorgeous palaces,</br>The solemn temples," like this wig must fall;</br>Their names shall die, their memory shall cease,</br>And Time's oblivious darkness bury all.
Then he, whose plaintive strains now mourn thy fate,</br>Must sure expect an humbler destiny;</br>For, never notic'd by the fair or great,</br>A simple, solitary bard is he.

No verse shall mourn, no stranger hear his fall—</br>Sometimes, perhaps, a barber's boy may tell,</br>(While, on coarse paper, stuck against the wall,</br>This verse adorns his shop) "I knew him well;

"Each weak to trim his visage sharp and thin</br>Was my employ — nor hard the task was found;</br>Twelve straggling hairs I scrap'd from off his chin,</br>Twelve more, behind, an inch of ribbon bound.
"He lately disappear'd — but when, or where</br>He went, or how, or why he's gone,</br>None know, nor do I think that any care,</br>For he, while here, appear'd to care for none.
"Thoughtful and silent in the shop he sat;</br>No object seem'd his vacant eye to call;</br>He heeded none of all our various chat;</br>And now we hear of him no more — that's all."</br>
